        <content><?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>
<ProcurementDocument>
    <SchemaVersionUsed>2.5.1</SchemaVersionUsed>
    <ProcurementInstrumentForm>DD 1155</ProcurementInstrumentForm>
    <OriginatorDetails>
        <InternalDocumentNumber>1143555</InternalDocumentNumber>
        <DoDSystem>
            <DITPRNumber>00000431</DITPRNumber>
            <SystemAdministratorDoDAAC>W8136G</SystemAdministratorDoDAAC>
        </DoDSystem>
    </OriginatorDetails>
    <AwardInstrument>
        <ProcurementInstrumentHeader>
            <ProcurementInstrumentIdentifier>
                <ProcurementInstrumentOrigin>Department of Defense</ProcurementInstrumentOrigin>
                <ProcurementInstrumentVehicle>Delivery Order</ProcurementInstrumentVehicle>
                <ProcurementInstrumentNumber>
                    <EnterpriseIdentifier>W50NH9</EnterpriseIdentifier>
                    <Year>21</Year>
                    <ProcurementInstrumentTypeCode>F</ProcurementInstrumentTypeCode>
                    <SerializedIdentifier>0032</SerializedIdentifier>
                </ProcurementInstrumentNumber>
                <ProcurementInstrumentDescription>Represented Contract</ProcurementInstrumentDescription>
            </ProcurementInstrumentIdentifier>
            <ProcurementInstrumentIdentifier>
                <ProcurementInstrumentOrigin>Department of Defense</ProcurementInstrumentOrigin>
                <ProcurementInstrumentVehicle>Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity</ProcurementInstrumentVehicle>
                <ProcurementInstrumentNumber>
                    <EnterpriseIdentifier>HHM402</EnterpriseIdentifier>
                    <Year>19</Year>
                    <ProcurementInstrumentTypeCode>D</ProcurementInstrumentTypeCode>
                    <SerializedIdentifier>0012</SerializedIdentifier>
                </ProcurementInstrumentNumber>
                <ProcurementInstrumentDescription>Ordering Instrument</ProcurementInstrumentDescription>
            </ProcurementInstrumentIdentifier>
            <BasicInformation>
                <TransmissionAcknowledgement>Acknowledge Receipt With No Detail and Change</TransmissionAcknowledgement>
                <ProcurementInstrumentName>Delivery Order (DD 1155)</ProcurementInstrumentName>
                <ContingencyContract>false</ContingencyContract>
                <DocumentPurpose>Original</DocumentPurpose>
                <EmergencyRequestContract>false</EmergencyRequestContract>
                <MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                    <MiscellaneousText>Deliveries or Performance
                        DELIVERIES OR PERFORMANCE
                        F.1&#9;Period of Performance (POP):

                        &#9;Base Period (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2021 - 07 APR 2022
                        &#9;Option Year 1 (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2022 &#8211; 07 APR 2023
                        &#9;Option Year 2 (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2023 &#8211; 07 APR 2024
                        &#9;Option Year 3 (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2024 &#8211; 07 APR 2025
                        &#9;Option Year 4 (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2025 &#8211; 07 APR 2026
                        &#9;FAR 52.217-8 Option (6 Months):&#9;08 APR 2026 &#8211; 07 OCT 2026

                        F.2&#9;Phase-In:  The 45-day Phase-In period will be included within the base period.

                        F.3&#9;The Government will have the unilateral right to exercise any options, in whole or in part.








                    </MiscellaneousText>
                    <Section>F</Section>
                </MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                <MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                    <MiscellaneousText>Contract Administration Data
                        CONTRACT ADMINISTRATION DATA
                        G.1&#9;Electronic Submission via Wide Area WorkFlow (WAWF):  Contractors must register and begin submitting electronic invoices immediately through the WAWF Receipt and Acceptance Internet site: https://wawf.eb.mil/.  Online training may be accessed at https://wawftraining.com.  Use the following data elements to invoice for services or supplies procured via this contract:
                        &#9;- The contract and task order number indicated on the award document.
                        G.2&#9;Contractor Monthly Status Report:  Contractors shall provide supporting documentation to the Contracting Officer through the Contracting Officer&#8217;s Representative (COR) that reconciles labor cost elements with the WAWF invoicing.  Supporting data shall include labor cost elements broken down as follows:
                        a.&#9;Labor - Identify individuals that worked, the hourly rate, and the number of hours worked.
                        b.&#9;Travel - COR approval notices and the receipts to support the travel dollars spent.
                        c.&#9;ODCs/Materials - COR approval notices, a description of what was purchased, and the receipts to support what items were purchased and the cost of those items.
                        d.&#9;Subcontractors - Identify the individuals that worked, the fully burdened labor rates (FBLRs), and the number of hours worked.
                        e.&#9;Indirect Expenses and Fee - Identify the amount of indirect expense and fee billed to the Government.
                        G.3&#9;Invoices:
                        G.3.1&#9;All invoices, including any supporting documentation, must be submitted electronically, via email, to the Task Order&#8217;s COR and Contract Specialist on the same day that it is submitted into
                        G.3.2.1&#9;The monthly invoice period is defined as the first calendar day of each month to the last calendar day of each month.
                        G.3.2.2&#9;Prior month invoices shall be submitted no later than the 10th working day of the following month.
                        G.3.2.3&#9;When submitting invoices, the contractor shall utilize a Standard Form (SF) 1034 as the coversheet to accompany its supporting documentation. Individual Accounting Classification Reference Numbers (ACRNs)/CLINs/sub-CLINs being billed must be annotated as separate lines on the SF 1034. Each category (i.e., labor, ODCs, etc.) shall be invoiced separately. The contractor shall also submit supporting documentation separating labor, ODCs, and travel.
                        G.3.2.4&#9;The contractor shall utilize a file naming convention for its supporting documentation when submitting the entire monthly invoice package electronically, via email, and when submitting into WAWF. The naming conventions should follow this format: INVOICE#_LABOR, OWC, TRAVEL, BY/OP_MON/Yr. (example: 12345_Labor OPT1_JAN17, 12345_ODC OPT1_JAN17, etc.). The invoice number assigned by the contractor should match what has been entered into WAWF, without variances.
                        G.3.2.5&#9;The contractor shall submit a draft of the invoice and all supporting documentation to the COR at least three business days prior to submitting the invoices in WAWF, for review and feedback.
                        G.3.2.6&#9;At the &#8220;Post-Award Orientation,&#8221; the Prime Contractor shall provide a sample Task Order Ceiling Compliance Report (see CDRL A081). The Prime Contractor shall provide supporting documentation, which includes a Microsoft Excel File that demonstrates how it will comply with the Task Order Ceiling Rates. A Microsoft Excel File listing sample invoiced employees and hours for each Blended Labor Category Rate and all applicable burdens (Indirect Expenses) for the Blended Labor Category Rate that make up the Fully Burdened Labor Rate, Less Fee. Additionally, the Prime Contractor shall demonstrate how the sample Fully Burdened Labor Rate, Less Fee, maps to the applicable Ceiling Rate for the blended labor category and maps to the invoiced labor on the SF 1034 and in WAWF. The Prime Contractor will be required to demonstrate compliance with the 10% CONUS ceiling amounts and the 20% OCONUS ceiling amounts.
                        G.3.2.7&#9;Labor:  The contractor may start billing employee labor as defined in PWS 1.6.22.3.
                        G.3.2.8&#9;For Labor CLINs, the contractor shall annotate all Labor on the monthly SF 1034. The contractor shall submit one Labor invoice, per month, which shall be invoiced separately from the other categories. All supporting documentation shall be separated based on the above file naming conventions and included as part of the entire month invoice package. In accordance with CDRL A081, supporting documentation will include a monthly reconciliation of actual &#8220;Blended&#8221; Labor Category incurred costs for the Prime and Subcontractors that demonstrates contractual compliance with the proposed Ceiling Rates.
                        G.3.2.8.1&#9;Note that for the purposes of invoicing on this effort, &#8220;Direct Labor&#8221; shall include the effective labor rate, any premium for security clearance, any premium for working shifts, and any allocation of Non-discretionary Bonuses that are collected and spread across all invoiced hours. Any premiums for security clearance is the amount of incentive pay that an employee receives for having a security clearance. Any premiums for working shifts is an amount added to the &#8220;Effective Labor Rate&#8221; for working shifts. Any Non-discretionary Bonus is a Recruitment, Retention, or Completion Bonus typically paid to an employee based on an employer/employee agreement. For the purpose of this Task Order, Offerors are required to allocate any Non-discretionary Bonuses across all of the hours an employee works in a year.
                        G.3.2.9&#9;In accordance with PWS 1.6.26 and CDRL A081, the Task Order Ceiling Compliance Report shall be traceable to the invoices submitted in WAWF.
                        G.3.2.10&#9;The contractor shall also provide a monthly roster to support the total number of FTEs on each invoice and shall be traceable to the Task Order Ceiling Compliance Report. The roster shall detail:  employee number, employee name, labor category, and number of days performing on contract during the month (CDRL A081).
                        G.3.2.11&#9;Other Direct Costs (ODCs)
                        G.3.2.11.1&#9;For ODC CLINs, the contractor shall annotate all ODCs on the monthly SF 1034. The contractor shall submit one ODC invoice, per month, which shall be invoiced separately from other categories. The ODC supporting documentation shall be separate from the contractor&#8217;s labor documentation, but still included as part of the monthly invoice package.
                        G.3.2.11.2&#9;The contractor shall include a summary list of billed expenses, including detailed individual expense reports, receipts for purchases made that will be billed back to the Government, proof of any required authorization by KO or COR, and any other supporting documents (attached as backup).
                        G.3.2.11.3&#9;All invoiced ODCs must have proof of prior approval.
                        G.3.2.12&#9;Travel
                        G.3.2.12.1&#9;For Travel CLINs, the contractor shall annotate all combined travel on the monthly SF 1034. The contractor shall submit one travel invoice, per month, which shall be invoiced separately from other categories. The travel invoice shall be separate from the contractor&#8217;s labor invoice and ODC invoice.
                        G.3.2.12.2&#9;The contractor shall include a summary list of billed expenses, including individual expense reports, receipts for purchases made that will be billed back to the Government, proof of any required authorization by the KO or COR, copies of original receipts for expenses incurred associated with travel that will be billed back to the Government, and any other necessary supporting documents (attached as backup).
                        G.3.2.12.3&#9;Approval shall be in accordance with the appropriate approval process corresponding to the type of travel being reimbursed, in accordance with the terms of the IDIQ contract and the task order.
                        G.3.2.12.4&#9;Documentation shall be organize by each unique employee. Travel vouchers shall include a description of the purpose of the travel. Accounting systems screenshots do not constitute adequate documentation for travel.
                        G.3.2.13&#9;Non-discretionary Bonuses or Incentive pay shall be traceable to the specific employee and amortized across all applicable hours and comply with the requirements at FAR 31.205-6(a), (b), and (f). Supporting documentation should include traceability between the amounts invoiced, any Bonus Expense Pool, and the roster of employees. The Prime Contractor shall amortize any incentive bonuses when preparing the Task Order Ceiling Compliance Report (CDRL A081) and allocate across all applicable hours.
                        G.3.2.14&#9;Trailing Charges:  For any changes that the contractor does not include in a particular month&#8217;s initial invoice (&#8220;trailing charges&#8221;), the contractor shall submit a separate invoice for such trailing charges and will not commingle trailing charges with an invoice for a different month of performance. Any &#8220;Tune-Up&#8221; as a result of reconciliation between actual incurred labor costs and the Ceiling Rate will be submitted on a separate invoice at the end of the contractor fiscal year.
                        G.3.3&#9;If a contractor believes that its policies and procedures meet the criteria outlined in Defense Contract Audit Agency Pamphlet No. 7641.90, &#8220;Information for Contractors,&#8221; the contractor may write to its cognizant Defense Contract Audit Agency (DCAA) office to request participation in the direct billing program.  The pamphlet is available via the Internet at https://www.dcaa.mil.  If DCAA determines that a contractor is eligible to participate in the direct billing program, a copy of the DCAA authorization memorandum must be sent to the Contracting Officer
                    </MiscellaneousText>
                    <Section>G</Section>
                </MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                <MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                    <MiscellaneousText>Special Contract Requirements
                        SPECIAL CONTRACT REQUIREMENTS
                        H.1 &#9;Task Order Ceiling and Option Exercise:  Services required under this task order shall not exceed 1,293,600 productive hours including surge. Pursuant to FAR 52.217-8, &#8220;Option to Extend Services,&#8221; and FAR 52.217-9, &#8220;Option to Extend the Term of the Contract,&#8221; the Government may exercise these hours, in whole or in part, from the option labor pool at any time during the life of the task order. The Fixed-Fee for each option exercise shall be calculated based upon the composite rate for the option period during which the option is exercised (see Attachment 0003 - GFPM).
                        Each time the contractor invoices for fee, it shall calculate a cumulative billable fee amount by identifying the amount of hours expended for each labor category multiplied by the fixed fee for each respective labor category.
                        &#9;Ceiling Hours&#9; 1,293,600
                        &#9;Hours Exercised&#9;    188,160
                        &#9;Hours Remaining&#9; 1,105,440
                        H.1.1 &#9;This task order includes option hours as identified in H.1 above and Attachment 0003 &#8211; GFPM .
                        H.2.2&#9;The Government reserves the right to exercise any or all of the option hours, against any labor category or combination of labor categories, at any time during task order performance, subject to the following restrictions:
                        H.2.2.1&#9;The Government may unilaterally exercise optional hours under this effort, provided that the Government exercises no less than 120 hours and no more than 235,200 hours under any single option exercise.
                        H.2.2.2&#9;The Government will provide the contractor at least 15 calendar day notice of its intent to exercise options under this provision.
                        H.2.2.3&#9;The surge option labor rate applied shall conform to the rate supplied within the option labor section of Attachment 0003 - GFPM for the period in which the option is exercised. The applicable labor rate for the option is determined by the date on which the option is awarded, not by dates of performance.
                        H.2.2.4&#9;The contractor shall begin performing services no later than 15 calendar days after the Government exercises a surge option.
                        H.2.2.5&#9;Notwithstanding H.2.2.1 through H.2.2.4 above, the Government may exercise and/or fund to support urgent operations not requiring the addition of additional contractor personnel (i.e., overtime or extended work week hours) in any amount, which is not subject to the quantity or timing restrictions identified above.
                        H.3&#9;Reserved
                        H.4 &#9;The Contractor shall not exceed the total hours exercised for each contract period. The contractor shall notify the COR and Contracting Officer, in writing, when 80% of the hours exercised in any performance period have been expended, and include the date at which it estimates all hours will be expended to occur. Hours stated in Attachment 0003 - GFPM  Supplement are estimates only and are based on anticipated workload requirements. The COR, in coordination with the PCO, is authorized to approve hours exceeding 40 hours per work week as required to meet mission needs. Hours indicated in the GFPM are interchangeable between labor categories and will be jointly reconciled within 60 calendar days of the end of each contract period written modification to align actual hours worked and costs expended.
                        H.4.1&#9;In accordance with FAR 52.232-22 Limitation of Funds, the Contractor shall notify the Contracting Officer in writing whenever it has reason to believe that the costs it expects to incur under this contract in the next 60 days, when added to all costs previously incurred, will exceed 75 percent of the total amount so far allotted to the contract by the Government.&#9;
                        H.5 &#9;Ceiling Rates are equal to the Offeror&#8217;s proposed fully burdened labor rates (less fee) plus 10% for CONUS labor categories and 20% for OCONUS labor categories and are not to be exceeded when billing the Government.
                    </MiscellaneousText>
                    <Section>H</Section>
                </MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                <MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                    <MiscellaneousText>List of Documents, Exhibits and Other Attachments
                        LIST OF ATTACHMENTS
                        J.1&#9;Reference the following attachments:
                        Attachment 0001 - DD 254 Contract Security Classification Specification
                        Attachment 0002 - Contract Data Requirements List (CDRL)
                        Attachment 0003 - Government Format Pricing Model (GFPM)
                        Attachment 0004 - Reserved
                        Attachment 0005 - Reserved
                        Attachment 0006 - Reserved
                        Attachment 0007 - Reserved
                        Attachment 0008 - Mission Essential Contractor Services
                    </MiscellaneousText>
                    <Section>J</Section>
                </MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                <MiscellaneousTextDetails>
                    <MiscellaneousText>Descriptions and Specifications
                        PWS
                        PERFORMANCE WORK STATEMENT (PWS)


                        INSCOM Counterintelligence (CI) and Human Intelligence (HUMINT) Support Services

                        Part 1

                        General Information

                        1.  General: This is a services contract to provide Analytical and Support Services to U.S. Army Counterintelligence (CI) and Human Intelligence (HUMINT) operations. This Analytical and Support Services requirement supports U.S. Army Intelligence and Security Command (INSCOM) Headquarters (HQ) and its Major Subordinate Commands (MSC) and activities. The Government shall not exercise any supervision or control over the contract service providers performing the services herein. Such contract service providers shall be accountable solely to the Contractor who, in turn is responsible to the Government.

                        1.1 Description of Services/Introduction: The Contractor shall provide personnel, equipment, supplies, transportation, tools, materials, supervision, and other items and non-personal services necessary to perform the CI and HUMINT Support Services as defined in this Performance Work Statement (PWS) except for those items specified as Government furnished property (GFP), Government facilities, and Government provided services. The Contractor shall perform to the standards in this contract.

                        1.2 Background: The protection of critical United States Forces&#8217; personnel, facilities, and information from foreign adversaries is a priority mission of the INSCOM. Protecting this technology and information and resolving vulnerabilities will increase the survivability of personnel, facilities, and information.

                        In order to conduct intelligence, analytical, cyber, forensics support, technology protection, intelligence analysis, and computer science to support CI and analytical analysis for military commanders and national decision makers, INSCOM will evolve the Army Counterintelligence (CI) and Human Intelligence (HUMINT) enterprise. This transformation and evolution includes the integration of multi-discipline platforms and capabilities, while enhancing CI and HUMINT operations at the tactical, operational, and strategic levels. As part of the Army&#8217;s Intel 2020 vision in accordance with (IAW) Army Regulation (AR) 381-10, 3 May 2007, U.S. Army Intelligence Activities: DoD Regulation 5240.1-R and Executive Order 12333, INSCOM&#8217;s priority is to thoughtfully shape the intelligence force and operations to enhance Theater Military Intelligence capabilities as specified in this PWS.

                        1.3 Objectives: The objectives of this PWS are for INSCOM to provide more responsive acquisition of services for current and future Army intelligence, security, and information operations requirements and related support services. These services will supply resources that support a breadth and depth of various missions including: conducting analytical support, cyber support and forensics, technology protection, intelligence analysis, and computer science analysis, to support INSCOM major subordinate commands and activities Army-wide concurrently while operating under the Headquarters, U.S. Army Intelligence and Security Command.

                        1.4 Scope: The Contractor shall provide highly qualified personnel to support the CI and HUMINT mission. Services include support to intelligence, analysis, cyber, forensics, technology protection, and computer science. The Contractor personnel must have knowledge of Intelligence Cycle, Intelligence Support/Role in the Military Decision Making Process (MDMP), CI Flags and knowledge of Foreign Intelligence Entity (FIE) Tactical Technical Procedures (TTPs), and knowledge of Distributed Common Ground System-Army (DCGS-A). As well, the Contractor shall have knowledge of HUMINT collection operations.

                        In support of this performance work statement, the contractor shall conduct research and analysis and provide conclusions and recommendations to support the following:

                        (i)&#9;INSCOM Headquarters (Fort Belvoir, VA)
                        (ii)&#9;Army G2X (Fort Belvoir, VA, Columbia, MD)
                        (iii)&#9;470th Military Intelligence Brigade (Fort Sam Houston, TX) and its subordinate organizations
                        (iv)&#9;500th Military Intelligence Brigade (Fort Shafter, HI) and its subordinate organizations
                        (v) &#9;513th Military Intelligence Brigade (Fort Gordon, GA) and its subordinate organizations
                        (vi) &#9;344th Military Intelligence Battalion (Goodfellow AFB, TX)
                        (vii)&#9;207th Military Intelligence Group (Vicenza, IT) and its subordinate organizations

                        1.5 Period of Performance: The period of performance shall be for one (1) Base Period of twelve (12) months (including 45-day Transition Period), and four (4) Option Periods of twelve (12) months as follows:

                        Base Period  (12 Months):&#9;&#9;08 APR 2021 - 07 APR 2022
                        &#9;Option Year 1 (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2022 &#8211; 07 APR 2023
                        &#9;Option Year 2 (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2023 &#8211; 07 APR 2024
                        &#9;Option Year 3 (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2024 &#8211; 07 APR 2025
                        &#9;Option Year 4 (12 Months):&#9;08 APR 2025 &#8211; 07 APR 2026
                        &#9;FAR 52.217-8 Option (6 Months):&#9;08 APR 2026 &#8211; 07 OCT 2026

                        1.6 General Information:

                        1.6.1 Quality Control: The Contractor shall develop and maintain an effective quality control program (QCP) to ensure services are performed IAW this PWS. The Contractor shall develop and implement procedures to identify, prevent, and ensure non-recurrence of defective services. The Contractor&#8217;s QCP is the means by which it assures itself that its work complies with the requirement of the contract. The QCP will be delivered electronically to the Contracting Officer (KO), Contracting Officer&#8217;s Representative (COR), and Alternate Contracting Officer&#8217;s Representative (ACOR) within 30 calendar days after task order (TO) award, and within 5 calendar days when changes are made thereafter. After acceptance of the QCP, the Contractor shall receive the KO&#8217;s acceptance in writing of any proposed change to the QCP.

                        &#9;&#9;Deliverable: A001: Quality Control Plan

                        1.6.1.1 Quality Assurance Surveillance Plan (QASP): The Government QASP shall be used as the objective basis for determining the Contractor&#8217;s performance during any established reporting period.  This plan primarily focuses on the Government measures to ensure that the Contractor has performed IAW performance standards. The QASP is a living document that the Government may review and revise on a regular basis. The intent of the QASP is to ensure performance IAW the metrics set forth in the contract documents so that the Government receives the quality of services specified and only pays for the acceptable level of services it receives. The QASP defines how the performance standards will be applied, the frequency of surveillance, and the minimum acceptable defect rate(s).

                        1.6.2 Recognized Holidays: The Contractor is not required to perform services on the following federally recognized holidays:
                        New Year&#8217;s Day&#9;&#9;&#9;&#9;Labor Day
                        Martin Luther King Jr.&#8217;s Birthday&#9;&#9;Columbus Day
                        President&#8217;s Day&#9;&#9;&#9;&#9;Veteran&#8217;s Day
                        Memorial Day&#9;&#9;&#9;&#9;Thanksgiving Day
                        Independence Day&#9;&#9;               Christmas Day

                        1.6.3 Hours of Operation: The Contractor will provide personnel during work hours that meet Government mission requirements. This is typically an 8-hour duty day (plus &#189; hour lunch break), Monday through Friday. However, operational tempo may require work outside of normal hours.  Some positions may be required to work night shift.  These hours shall not exceed 40 hours per week without prior approval by the KO, COR, or ACOR.  The Contractor shall provide personnel during the Government core hours which are 0900-1500 Monday through Friday except Federal holidays or when the Government facility is closed due to local or national emergencies, administrative closings, or similar Government-directed facility closings. For other than a Firm Fixed Price contract, the Contractor will not be reimbursed when the Government facility is closed for the above reasons. The Contractor shall at all times maintain an adequate workforce for the uninterrupted performance of all tasks defined within this PWS when the Government facility is not closed for the above reasons. When hiring Contractor personnel, the Contractor shall keep in mind that workforce stability and continuity are essential.

                        1.6.3.1 Extended Hours/Continuity of Operations:  Contractor work schedules will be established and monitored based on unit mission needs and be documented by the Contractor Site Lead. The Government may require contract support outside of this normal work schedule, including on Federal holidays, in order to accommodate the schedules of geographically-dispersed supported elements. In the execution of a Continuity of Operations Plan (COOP) training or actual event, select Contractor personnel may be required to evacuate and relocate to an approved COOP location.  The COOP operational hours will require extended overtime that includes weekends and holidays.  Should a COOP event occur, the COR will provide additional guidance for COOP planning, training, and execution.

                        1.6.4 Place of Performance: The work to be performed under this contract will be primarily performed at Government-owned or leased secure work facilities at the following locations:

                        (i)&#9;Fort Gordon, GA; (15 Contractor Manpower Equivalents (CMEs))
                        (ii)&#9;Fort Shafter, HI: (9 CMEs)
                        (iii)&#9;Columbia, MD; (2 CMES)
                        (iv)&#9;Fort Belvoir, VA; (54 CMEs)
                        (v)&#9;Fort Sam Houston, TX; (11 CMEs)
                        (vi)&#9;Vicenza, Italy; (3 CMEs)
                        &#9;(vii)&#9;Goodfellow AFB, TX; (1 CME)

                        1.6.4.1 Contractor Telework: Under normal circumstances, contractor personnel are not authorized to telework for the performance of services under this PWS. However, in extraordinary circumstances (e.g. National Emergencies, extreme weather, Government shutdowns, and COOP scenarios), the KO or COR may authorize or require  some or all contractor personnel to telework.  If  the KO or COR officially authorizes or requires telework, the contractor must be willing to waive the Place of Performance provision in the contract and ensure that there will be no additional costs to the US Government associated with the telework.  For positions affected by the telework authorization or requirement in accordance with this paragraph, the contractor shall not bill labor hours except for hours actually teleworked.

                        1.6.4.2 If contractor personnel telework as authorized or required in accordance with paragraph 1.6.4.1, the contractor shall coordinate with the COR regarding the completion of tasks to be performed by contractor personnel during telework. The contractor shall coordinate with the COR to ensure contractor personnel complete as many job-related tasks as possible and, if authorized by the KO or COR, complete training in support of task order performance. The Government will not provide any equipment or network connections to facilitate contractor telework, and the contractor shall ensure teleworking personnel have access to necessary equipment and network connections at no added cost to the Government. The KO or the COR may rescind telework authorizations or requirements at any time, and the contractor shall ensure its personnel cease teleworking and report to their required duty stations as specified by the KO or COR.

                        1.6.4.3 In the event of extraordinary circumstances, such as those that would lead the KO or the COR to authorize or require telework, the KO or the COR may require the contractor to provide daily personnel status reports in order to facilitate accountability. In these cases, the contractor shall provide daily personnel status reports, in contractor format, to the KO, COR, and contract specialist at no additional cost to the US Government. This guidance shall expire once the local area returns to regular operating conditions or once rescinded in writing by the KO or COR.

                        &#9;Deliverable A080: Daily Status Report

                        1.6.5 Type of Contract: The Government anticipates award of a Cost-Plus Fixed Fee (CPFF) &#8211; Level of Effort (LOE) type contract for labor, with Cost Reimbursable (No-Fee) Travel and Other Direct Costs (ODCs)/Materials.  For the purposes of this task order, the specified level of effort is based on one CME equating to 1,920 labor hours.  This is a non-personal services task order.  The Government shall not exercise any supervision or control over the Contractor&#8217;s service providers in their performance of the services indicated in this PWS.  Contractor service providers shall be accountable solely to the Contractor, which, in turn, is accountable to the Government.

                        1.6.6 Security Requirements: Contractor personnel performing work under this contract shall have a Top Secret (TS) clearance and be eligible for Special Compartmented Information (SCI) access at time work begins on contract and shall maintain the level of security required for the life of the contract.  Upon being granted SCI access, contractor personnel may be submitted and must be approved for Visit Access Request (VARS) access.  Contractor personnel must maintain their TS/SCI and VARS access for the life of the contract. Contractor personnel must be willing to complete a CI Polygraph examination at any time it is required. This will be determined by the task, and also when special program access is needed.  Contractor personnel may require Intelligence Community Badges based on their duty position and as determined by the COR in coordination with the Contactor&#8217;s Government lead. The security requirements are IAW the attached DD Form 254. (Attachment 1)

                        1.6.6.1 Contractor performance requires a TS/SCI clearance, TS safeguarding capabilities, and staffing with Contractor personnel cleared to the TS level. All Contractor personnel performing under this contract shall be U.S. Citizens, and those requiring SCI access shall have a final TS clearance with Single Scope Background Investigation (SSBI) and shall be eligible for indoctrination to the SCI level. Some positions shall require HUMINT Control Systems (HCS) access, Gamma (G) access, and CI polygraph. The Contractor shall maintain and administer a security program IAW the National Industrial Security Program Operations Manual (NISPOM) DoD 5220.22M. Applicable security regulations are specified in the DD254 and the SCI addendum. Loss or suspension of required security clearance as set forth on the DD Form 254, &#8220;Contract Security Classification Specifications,&#8221; would result in the Contractor&#8217;s inability to perform IAW the terms and conditions of this contract. As a result of this failure to perform, the Contractor is subject to termination under the appropriate termination clause herein.

                        1.6.6.2 The Contractor&#8217;s Facility Security Officer (FSO) shall act as the primary liaison between the Contractor, the COR, and INSCOM Special Security Officer (SSO) on all matters pertaining to security.

                        1.6.6.3 The Contractor shall obtain and maintain user accounts for Army Knowledge Online (AKO), Unclassified but Sensitive Internet Protocol Router Network (i.e., Non-Classified Internet Protocol Router Network (NIPRNET)), Secret Internet Protocol Router Network (SIPRNET), and Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications Systems (JWICS) accounts, including email, for its personnel where the networks are available.  Contractor personnel shall obtain and maintain the necessary access cards and certificates to access the required classified and unclassified information technology networks.

                        1.6.6.4 Personnel Security Clearances: The Contractor shall be responsible for processing all necessary security clearances and identification of Contractor personnel. All such personnel are entitled to a Common Access Card (CAC) for computer access and may be entitled to a CAC for logistical support in overseas areas. See AR 600-8-14 (Jun 09) and AR 715-9 (Jun 11) for more information. The Contractor shall ensure that all badges and cards are returned to the COR and Government accounts are closed whenever an employee is no longer assigned to this TO or at the end of the period of performance. An integral part of the manning requirements includes the requirement for a security clearance. Strict adherence to the policies and procedures governing security clearances is required. The Contractor must be prudent in the screening and selection of personnel that shall be subjected to a background investigation. All Contractor personnel assigned to or visiting Contiguous United States (CONUS) or OCONUS Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility (SCIF) locations (including during the Phase-In period) must be cleared for TS and be indoctrinated for SCI prior to beginning contract performance. For initial assignment, transfer and temporary duty (TDY), clearance certification must be submitted to the COR at least 21 calendar days prior to the anticipated arrival at destination. Most stations require different levels of access and some stations may require polygraphs. When access to a station requires a polygraph, the Contractor shall be allowed 90 days from the time written notice is issued by the Government to have polygraph-cleared personnel ready to deploy.

                        1.6.6.5 Army Special Access Program (SAP) Programs: Defense contractor personnel requiring access to Army SAP information, as defined by AR 380-381, must agree to undergo random counterintelligence-scope polygraph examinations, when required by proper authority, to determine suitability for receiving and maintaining access to SAP information. Contractors will certify prior to TO award, or subsequent to award, but prior to commencement of duties for new employees, that all personnel so identified have freely consented to such examination. Contractor personnel who withdraw their consent at any time during their period of access must be immediately removed from access to SAP information, and such action must be promptly reported to the KO or such party as the KO directs. Additional information about polygraphs and DD Form 254 for SAPs is contained in AR 380-381 including the requirement for distribution of a copy of all DD Forms 254 in support of SAP contracts to be forwarded to Headquarters Department of the Army (HQDA) (DACS-DMP), Room 10711, 200 Army Pentagon, Washington, DC 20310-0200.

                        1.6.6.6 Polygraphs:   Contractors may be required by the Government for a Counterintelligence polygraph (CIPG) to be conducted by Government Polygraph Program personnel. Application of the CIPG must receive prior approval by the COR.  Results of the polygraph shall be submitted to Central Clearance Facility (CCF) for determination of eligibility for interim access to SCI material.  Contractor support personnel shall be subject to Counterintelligence screening/re-screening at any stage of employment and at any time with and without notice and may be selected for polygraph screening or re-screening at the discretion of the Government.

                        1.6.6.6.1 Individuals requiring access to the National Security Agency&#8217;s (NSA) network(s) must possess TS/SCI clearances and agree in writing to complete a polygraph.

                        1.6.6.7 Drug Testing:  The Contractor shall ensure that its personnel maintain a program for achieving a drug free work force IAW DoD Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement (DFARS) clause 252.223-7004 (&#8220;Drug-free Work Force&#8221;) and local policies regarding drug testing.  The Contractor shall conduct drug tests, ensuring all TS cleared Contractor employees are tested at least once per year each year of the contract, as well as when there is reasonable suspicion that an employee uses illegal drugs.  The drug testing shall be at the Contractor&#8217;s expense.  Positive drug test results shall be made available to both KO and COR within 24 hours of known test results.  Yearly records of drug testing shall be made available to the COR.

                        1.6.7 Physical Security: The Contractor shall be responsible for safeguarding all Government equipment, information, and property provided for Contractor use. At the close of each work period, Government facilities, equipment, and materials shall be secured IAW with the local Physical Security Standard Operating Procedure (SOP).

                        1.6.7.1 Handling or Access to Classified Information:  Contractor shall comply with Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) 52.204-2, Security Requirements.  This clause involves access to information classified &#8220;Confidential,&#8221; &#8220;Secret,&#8221; or &#8220;Top Secret&#8221; and requires contractors to comply with the Security Agreement (DD&#160;Form&#160;441), including the National Industrial Security Program Operating Manual (DoD 5220.22-M Change 4), and any revisions to DOD 5220.22-M Change 4, notice of which has been furnished to the Contractor. This contract requires the Contractor to access, release, and transmit classified information. The Contractor shall not disseminate or publish, except amongst its own personnel and any Subcontractors, information developed under this contract or contained in the reports to be furnished pursuant to this contract without prior written approval of the KO. Physical, personnel, information, and operational security measures are part of the security specifications for this contract as outlined in the DD Form 254, IAW emerging Intelligence Community Directives (ICDs), Director of Central Intelligence Directives (DCIDs), NISPOM Supplements, and all other Government security regulations and directives. The Contractor shall be responsible for furnishing classification guidance to its employees for services to be performed. The Contractor shall comply with special instructions and controls for handling, processing, storing, and transmission of classified information IAW applicable Government regulations, manuals, and directives. Additional SCI security requirements are delineated in the addendum to the DD Form 254 (Attachment 1).

                        1.6.7.2 Key Control: The Contractor shall establish and implement methods of making sure all keys and key cards issued to the Contractor by the Government are not lost or misplaced and are not used by unauthorized persons. NOTE: All references to keys include key cards. No keys issued to the Contractor by the Government shall be duplicated. The Contractor shall develop procedures covering key control that shall be included in the Quality Control Plan. Such procedures shall include turn-in of any issued keys by personnel who no longer require access to locked areas. The Contractor shall immediately report any occurrences of lost or duplicate keys and key cards to the KO. In the event keys, other than master keys, are lost or duplicated, the Contractor shall, upon direction of the KO, re-key or replace the affected lock or locks; however, the Government, at its option, may replace the affected lock or locks or perform re-keying. When the replacement of locks or re-keying is performed by the Government, the total cost of re-keying or the replacement of the lock or locks shall be deducted from the monthly payment due the Contractor. In the event a master key is lost or duplicated, all locks and keys for that system shall be replaced by the Government and the total cost deducted from the monthly payment due the Contractor. The Contractor shall prohibit the use of Government issued keys and key cards by any persons other than the Contractor&#8217;s employees. The Contractor shall prohibit the opening of locked areas by Contractor employees to permit entrance of persons other than Contractor employees engaged in the performance of assigned work in those areas or personnel authorized entrance by the KO.

                        1.6.7.3 Lock Combinations: The Contractor shall establish and implement methods of ensuring that all lock combinations are not revealed to unauthorized persons. The Contractor shall ensure that lock combinations are changed when personnel having access to the combinations no longer have a need to know such combinations.  These procedures shall be included in the Contractor&#8217;s QCP IAW with local security SOP.

                        1.6.8 Post-Award Orientation/Periodic Progress Meetings: The Contractor shall attend any post-award conference convened by the contracting activity or contract administration office IAW FAR 42.5. The post-award orientation shall be held within 15 calendar days of award. The Contractor shall schedule and conduct this meeting, in coordination with the COR, ACOR, and KO. No later than 3 business days before the orientation, the Contractor shall provide the COR, ACOR, and KO with the briefing slides. Within 3 business days after the meeting, the Contractor shall provide the minutes to the COR, ACOR, and KO.

                        &#9;&#9;Deliverable A002: Post &#8211; Award Brief Slides and Minutes with Attendees List

                        1.6.8.1 The purpose of the post-award orientation is to: 1) discuss any unique characteristics of the requirement; 2) identify stakeholders&#39; roles and responsibilities; and 3) establish a common understanding of cost, schedule, and performance expectations. The KO, COR, and other Government personnel, as appropriate, may meet periodically with the Contractor to review the Contractor&#39;s performance. At these meetings, the KO will apprise the Contractor of how the Government views the Contractor&#39;s performance and the Contractor will apprise the Government of problems, if any, being experienced. Appropriate action shall be taken to resolve outstanding issues. These meetings shall be at no additional cost to the Government.

                        1.6.9 Program Management Plan: The Contractor shall provide a Program Management Plan (PMP) within 15 calendar days after TO award. The PMP shall provide a resource-loaded schedule that outlines the steps that will be taken, the timeline to completion, and any associated risks with execution of the order. If a project tasking is submitted to the Contractor, the PMP will be updated within 15 calendar days of each new project tasking. The update shall specify estimated project start and stop dates as well as a risk mitigation plan and an expenditure plan aligned to key milestones within the project, to include any anticipated ODCs. The update should highlight any interdependencies within the tasks and the project(s) schedules. Upon acceptance and approval by the Government, the Contractor shall meet the cost, schedule and forecasted delivery date of all deliverables by taking all reasonable measures to fulfill the requirement, and shall report monthly status updates in the Monthly Status Report (MSR).

                        Deliverable: A003 - Program Management Plan (PMP),

                        1.6.10 Monthly Status Report: The MSR shall provide detailed status for the project(s) within the PMP as well as capture an overall status of the order.  The MSR reports cost, schedule, and performance against PWS requirements and identifies status of funding, planned versus actual expenditures per project, status of known risks, risk mitigation efforts, deliverables funded and date they were funded, technical progress made and schedule status per deliverable, the titles, dates and number(s) of deliverables completed, and the deliverables scheduled to be delivered during the upcoming month. The MSR shall report all Military Interdepartmental Purchase Request (MIPRs) received and shall detail the funding source of each MIPR. Specific MSR format and content shall be mutually agreed upon by the contractor and the COR; this should be established no later than the Post-Award Orientation. The Contractor shall submit this report for a given month no later than the last day of the following month (e.g., the report for 1 May through 31 May shall be submitted no later than 30 June).  If the MSR shows that a project is not meeting the performance thresholds set forth in the Performance Requirements Summary (PRS) found in Section 7.0, the Contractor shall provide in the MSR the rationale and circumstances preventing the threshold from being met, and provide an update to the PMP, to the satisfaction, acceptance and approval of the COR.

                        Deliverable:  A004 - Monthly Status Report

                        1.6.11 Contracting Officer&#8217;s Representative (COR):  The COR will be designated by a formal letter. The COR monitors all technical aspects of the contract and assists in contract administration. The COR is authorized to perform the following functions identified in the appointment letter: assure that the Contractor performs the technical requirements of the contract; perform inspections necessary in connection with contract performance; maintain written and oral communications with the Contractor concerning technical aspects of the contract; issue written interpretations of technical requirements, including Government drawings, designs, and specifications; monitor the Contractor&#39;s performance and notify both the KO and Contractor of any deficiencies; coordinate availability of GFP; and provide worksite entry for Contractor personnel. The COR&#8217;s formal designation letter, a copy of which is forwarded to the Contractor, states the responsibilities and limitations of the COR, especially with regard to changes in cost or price, estimates, or changes in delivery dates. The COR is not authorized to change any of the terms and conditions of the resulting task order.

                        1.6.12 Key Personnel: The following personnel are considered key due to the nature of the support provided, and all will be located at Fort Belvoir, VA:

                        (a)&#9;Program Manager&#9;&#9;&#9;(1 CME)
                        (b)&#9;Deputy Program Manager  &#9;               (1 CME)
                        (c)&#9;HUMINT Planner&#9;&#9;&#9;(1 CME)
                        (d)&#9;Intelligence Analysts&#9;&#9;&#9;(5 CMEs)
                        1.6.12.1 All Contractor personnel shall be identified by labor category and name at the conclusion of the transition period to the ACOR or COR by electronic mail. Key personnel and designated ACOR shall review proposed Contractor resumes to ensure skills and qualifications are met IAW the requirements of the PWS and provide a recommendation to the ACOR/COR/KO. Key personnel resumes shall be reviewed by the COR, however all Contractor resumes may be requested and reviewed by the COR or KO at any time. All contractor key personnel with the required skills and qualifications shall begin performing on the task order no later than fifteen (15) calendar days after task order award. All Contractor personnel accepted by the ACOR/COR or KO will start no later than 45 calendar days after TO award. The Contractor may not substitute or exchange Contractor personnel without prior written approval by the COR or KO. Before replacing any Contractor personnel, the Contractor shall notify the COR and KO no less than 30 calendar days in advance, submit written justification for replacement Contractor personnel, and provide the name and qualifications of any proposed replacement Contractor personnel. The Contractor shall not replace Contractor personnel without written approval from the COR or KO. The Contractor shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the COR or KO that the qualifications of the prospective personnel meet the contract requirements for the position to be filled.

                        1.6.12.1.1 The Contractor shall provide a program manager who shall be responsible for the performance of the work. The name of program manager and an alternate who shall act for the Contractor when the program manager is absent shall be designated in writing to the COR and KO. The program manager and the alternate shall have full authority to act for the Contractor on all contract matters relating to daily operation of this contract. The program manager or alternate shall be available between core hours of 0900-1500, Monday through Friday except Federal holidays or when the Government facility is closed for administrative reasons.

                        1.6.12.2 Contractor Key Personnel, Responsibilities and Training:  The Contractor shall assume responsibility for all functions outlined in this PWS upon TO award.  All contract company personnel, officers, and executives participating in or with knowledge of this mission will receive a detailed Threat Awareness and Reporting Program (TARP) brief and mission brief and will execute a Standard Form (SF) 312 (non-disclosure agreement) prior to any work commencing.  The Contractor shall also be responsible for compliance with all site and contract specific security policies and procedures. The Contractor shall certify to the COR in writing within thirty (30) calendars days of completion that all employees have met labor category specific minimum training and have received and completed INSCOM-mandated training.

                        1.6.12.3 Identification of Contractor Employees: All Contractor personnel attending meetings, answering Government telephones, and working in other situations where their Contractor status is not obvious to third parties are required to identify themselves as such to avoid creating an impression in the minds of members of the public that they are Government officials. The Contractor shall also ensure that documents or reports produced by its personnel are suitably marked as Contractor products or that Contractor participation is appropriately disclosed. Contractor personnel are required to obtain and wear appropriate identification badges IAW requirements at their Government Place of Performance. Business cards and signature blocks on correspondence shall clearly identify the individual as a Contractor and include the name of the Contractor&#8217;s company.

                        1.6.13 Contractor Travel: Contractor personnel will be required to travel within CONUS and OCONUS during the performance of this contract to attend meetings, conferences, and training. The Contractor may be required to travel to off-site training locations in support of this PWS. The Contractor will be authorized travel expenses consistent with the substantive provisions of the Joint Travel Regulation (JTR) and the limitation of funds specified in this contract. All Contractor travel requires Government approval or authorization and notification to the COR in advance of travel. A valid US unrestricted passport is required for personnel providing OCONUS site support. The cost of travel is provided for in the ODC Contract Line Item Number (CLIN) and will be IAW the applicable portions of the JTR. The contractor shall adhere to the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) clause.

                        1.6.13.1 Other Direct Costs: Contractor invoices shall include applicable documentation to support all actual costs incurred (e.g., airfare, rental vehicle, hotel, and lodging receipts). All travel and Government required training will be billed under ODCs. Contractors will be required to perform mandatory training at no cost to the contractor. The Government is providing an ODC plug number based on historical data from the previous vendor quotes.

                        1.6.13.2 Use of Government funds to pay for premium-class travel (first and business) is strictly forbidden. Exceptions for the use of Premium-class travel must be IAW the JTR and approved in writing by the KO or COR at least 15 days prior to travel. Invitational Travel Orders may be provided for use to obtain Government rates for hotel and motor vehicle rentals when traveling on official Government business.

                        1.6.13.3 The Contractor shall submit trip reports within five (5) days after completion of travel. If a trip extends more than two weeks, the Contractor shall submit interim reports every two weeks throughout the duration of the trip. Trip reports will summarize the reason for the trip, Government Official authorizing the trip, results of the trip, action items, and any other relevant information about the trip. Travel may be required to various CONUS and OCONUS locations and facilities in support of the mission.

                        1.6.14 OCONUS TRAVEL:

                        1.6.14.1 Contract personnel may require a business theater clearance for some OCONUS Locations.  All travel will be IAW the DoD Foreign Clearance Guide.
                        1.6.14.2 All travel requests must be approved in writing by the Government. Contract personnel may require a business theater clearance for some OCONUS locations.

                        1.6.14.3 The Contractor shall prepare and obtain all necessary travel documentation, inoculations, and permits that may be required for OCONUS locations, such as SOFA or Visas, when required.  All required documentation must be processed and approved prior to travel.
                        1.6.15 Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA): Relevant SOFA and related documents will be made available to the Contractor and copies will be provided upon request. The Contractor shall obtain all necessary legal advice concerning the content, meaning, and application of any applicable SOFAs and similar agreements. The Contractor shall adhere to all relevant provisions of the applicable SOFAs and other similar related agreements. The Contractor shall provide to the Government the required documentation to acquire invited contractor, if required by SOFA.

                        1.6.15.1 All OCONUS personnel must go thought the SOFA process and 700-19 process under the host Nation(s) that will allow the invited contractor (IC) or Technical Representative (TR) to obtain approval to work perform the work. The full SOFA and 700-19 process in its entirety is located under section 7 Attachments/Exhibits.

                        1.6.16 Organizational Conflicts of Interest (OCI): Contractor personnel performing work under this contract may receive, have access to, or participate in the evaluation of proprietary information or source selection information (e.g., cost or pricing information, budget information or analyses, specifications or work statements), or perform evaluation services related to the INSCOM Analytical support capabilities which may create a current or subsequent OCI as defined in FAR Subpart 9.5. The Contractor and Sub-contractor, and its personnel, are subject to all applicable Procurement Integrity Act and OCI rules including FAR Part 3. The Contractor shall notify the KO immediately whenever it becomes aware that such access or participation may result in any actual or potential OCI and shall promptly submit a plan to the KO to avoid or mitigate any such OCI.  The Contractor&#8217;s mitigation plan shall be determined to be acceptable solely at the discretion of the KO and in the event the KO unilaterally determines that any such OCI cannot be satisfactorily avoided or mitigated, the KO may affect other remedies as he or she deems necessary, including prohibiting the Contractor from participation in subsequent contracted requirements which may be affected by the OCI.

                        1.6.17 Data Rights: The Government has unlimited rights to all documents and materials produced under this contract. All documents and materials, to include the source codes of any software, produced under this contract shall be Government-owned and are the property of the Government with all rights and privileges of ownership/copyright belonging exclusively to the Government. These documents and materials may not be used or sold by the Contractor without written permission from the KO. All materials supplied to the Government shall be the sole property of the Government and may not be used for any other purpose. This right does not abrogate any other Government rights.

                        1.6.18 Training:  This PWS requires training that is unique to INSCOM or the Government.  The Government will not pay for contractor required training in order for contractor employees to achieve required certification levels required by the resultant contract.  Any current training, remedial, refresher, maintenance, or advancement to the next certification level and all associated costs are the responsibility of the contractor. The Government may offer specific duty related training opportunities to the contractor at no cost to the Government.  All such training will be coordinated with the COR and approved by the KO and charged via ODCs.

                        1.6.18.1 Mandatory Training:  The Contractor is required to ensure that all employees comply with the Mandatory Intelligence Training requirements for Contractor personnel IAW AR 381-10 (&#8220;U.S. Army Intelligence Activities&#8221;) and theater-required training if the employee is deployed overseas.  The Contractor must provide documentation to the COR that training has occurred and successfully completed for each employee.  The training is mandatory for all personnel in the Intelligence environment. Costs for this training is at no cost to the Contractor.  Additional training may be mandated by the Government as warranted, including:

                        (i)&#9;Annual DOD Cyber Awareness Challenge
                        (ii)&#9;Annual Security Refresher &#8211; INSCOM
                        (iii)&#9;Anti-Terrorism Force Protection Training
                        (iv)&#9;Combating Trafficking in Persons
                        (v)&#9;Intelligence Oversight
                        (vi)&#9;Classification Markings
                        (vii)&#9;Operations Security (OPSEC) Annual Training
                        (viii)&#9;Threat Awareness Reporting Program

                        1.6.18.2   Anti-Terrorism (AT) Level I Training:  All contractor employees, to include subcontractor employees, requiring access to Army installations, facilities, and controlled access areas shall complete AT Level 1 awareness training within 30 calendar days after contract start date.  The contractor shall submit certificates of completion for each affected contractor employee and subcontractor employee to the COR within 15 calendar days after completion of training by all employees and subcontractor personnel.  AT Level 1 awareness training is available at the following website:  https://jkodirect.jten.mil/Atlas2/page/login/Login.jsf

                        1.6.18.3 Antiterrorism and Force Protection (AT/FP):  AR 350-1, 19 August 2014, Army Training and Leadership Development, Section II, G-3/5/7, Antiterrorism and Force Protection. Specific Army standards for AT/FP training are listed in chapter 5, AR 525-13, 17 February 2017. Individual AT/FP training is mandatory for all soldiers, Department of the Army (DA) civilians, and DOD contractors and is strongly recommended for family members prior to travelling outside the 50 United States and its territories and possessions for any reason, including mobilization, temporary duty, permanent change of station, and leave. There is also an AT/FP training requirement for personnel stationed outside the United States. Individual AT/FP training is valid for one (1) year and must be documented.

                        &#9;&#9;Deliverable: A005 &#8211; Antiterrorism and Force Protection (AT/FP) Training Document

                        1.6.18.4 iWatch Training:   The Contractor and all associated sub-contractors shall brief all employees on the local iWATCH program (training standards provided by the requiring activity Authorization to Operate (ATO)).  This local developed training will be used to inform employees of the types of behavior to watch for and instruct employees to report suspicious activity to the COR/ACOR.  This training shall be completed within 30 calendar days of TO award and within 30 calendar days of new employee&#8217;s commencing performance.  iWATCH training results shall be reported to the COR/ACOR not later than 45 calendar days after TO award.

                        &#9;&#9;Deliverable A006 &#8211; iWatch Training Certificates

                        1.6.18.5 Army Training Certification Tracking System (ATCTS):  All Contractor employees who require access to a Government information system shall be registered in the Army Training Certification Tracking System (ATCTS) at commencement of services and shall successfully complete the DOD Information Assurance Awareness prior to access to the Information System and then annually thereafter.  The Contractor shall submit training certificates of completion to the COR within 15 calendar days after completion of training by all employees and Subcontractor personnel.

                        &#9;&#9;Deliverable A007 &#8211; Army Training Certification Tracking System (ATCTS) Certificates of
                        &#9;&#9;&#9;&#9;    Completion

                        1.6.18.6 Operations Security (OPSEC) Training Programs: The Contractor shall provide OPSEC training to all employees regarding the safeguarding of sensitive information prior to employees being allowed access to such information.   Chapter 4 of AR 530-1, Training, requires that newly arrived personnel receive an OPSEC orientation briefing within the first 30 days of arrival at the organization.  The AR further requires that all personnel receive an annual OPSEC briefing. Contractor personnel may utilize the OPSEC briefings presented by the INSCOM OPSEC Program Manager/Coordinator.  The Contractor will submit certificates of completion or sign in rosters all initial and annual OPSEC training to the COR.  The above requirements will flow down to all subcontractors working on or providing support to the contract.

                        &#9;&#9;Deliverable A008 &#8211; Operations Security (OPSEC) Training Programs Certificates of Completion

                        1.6.18.6.1 The Contractor shall not release sensitive information to the general public without prior written approval from the KO.  All contractor requests to release sensitive information shall be in writing and clearly explain the necessity for release of the information and consequences if approval is not granted.

                        1.6.18.6.2 All material produced by the contractor which will be released to the general public will be subject to OPSEC and Security reviews from  INSCOM OPSEC Officer, Security Officer, and INSCOM Public Affairs Office prior to release.

                        1.6.18.6.3 The Contractor shall destroy all sensitive program material at the completion of the contract so as to ensure the information cannot be accessed or utilized for any purpose.  The Contractor will also notify the KO in writing of its destruction. These same requirements will flow down to all subcontractors working on or provided any sensitive information related to the contract.

                        1.6.18.7 OPSEC Standing Operating Procedure/Plan: The Contractor shall develop an OPSEC Standing Operating Procedure (SOP)/Plan within ninety (90) calendar days of TO award, to be reviewed and approved by the responsible Government OPSEC officer, per AR 530-1 (&#8220;Operations Security&quot;). This SOP/Plan will include the Government&#39;s critical information, why it needs to be protected, where it is located, who is responsible for it, and how to protect it. In addition, the Contractor shall identify an individual who will be an OPSEC Coordinator. The Contractor shall ensure this individual becomes OPSEC Level II certified per AR 530-1.

                        &#9;Deliverable: A009 - OPSEC Standing Operating Procedure (SOP)/Plan

                        1.6.18.7.1   Performance or Delivery in a Foreign Country, Defense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement (DFARS) Clause 252.225-7043, Antiterrorism/Force Protection for Defense Contractors outside the US. The Contractor shall meet the AT requirement that non-local contractor personnel are to comply with theater clearance requirements and allow the combatant commander to exercise oversight to ensure the Contractor&#8217;s compliance with combatant commander and subordinate task force commander policies and directives.

                        1.6.18.8 Information Assurance Training (IA)/Information Technology (IT) Training:  All Contractor employees and associated sub-contractor employees must complete the DoD IA awareness training before issuance of network access and annually thereafter. All Contractor employees working IA/IT functions must comply with DOD and Army training requirements in DoD Directive 8570.01 (August 11, 2016), DoD 8570.01-M Change 4 (10 October 20150, and AR 25-2 upon initial employment.

                        1.6.18.9  Information Assurance (IA)/Information Technology (IT) Certification:  Per DoD 8570.01-M Change 4, DFARS 252.239-7001, and AR 25-2, the Contractor employees supporting IA/IT functions shall be appropriately certified upon TO award. The baseline certification as stipulated in DoD 8570.01-M Change 4 must be completed upon TO award.

                        1.6.19 Antiterrorism Considerations: IAW DFARS 225.172 Antiterrorism/force protection, and DoD Instruction O-2000.16, Volume 1, DoD Antiterrorism Standards, the Contractor is hereby advised that it shall comply with the policies and procedures of the U.S. Antiterrorism Officer (ATO) at each installation where work is being performed.

                        1.6.19.1 AT Awareness Training for Contractor Personnel Traveling Overseas: The Contractor shall ensure U.S.-based Contractor employees and associated sub-contractor employees complete Government-provided area of responsibility (AOR) specific AT awareness training as directed by AR 525-13. Specific AOR training content is directed by the combatant commander with the unit ATO being the local point of contact.

                        1.6.20 Access and General Protection/Security Policy and Procedures: The Contractor and all associated subcontractors employees shall comply with applicable installation, facility, and area commander installation/facility access and local security policies and procedures (provided by a Government representative). The Contractor shall also provide all information required for background checks to meet installation access requirements to be accomplished by installation Provost Marshal Office, Director of Emergency Services or Security Office. The Contractor workforce must comply with all personal identity verification requirements as directed by DOD, HQDA, and local policy. In addition to the changes otherwise authorized by the changes clause of this contract, should the Force Protection Condition (FPCON) at any individual facility or installation change, the Government may require changes in contractor security matters or processes.


                        1.6.21 Government Transportation:

                        1.6.21.1 Use of Vehicles:  As deemed necessary by the unit Commander, the Contractor employees shall be trained and properly licensed IAW AR 600-55 (&#8220;The Army Driver and Operator Standardization Program&#8221;) and local directives, regulations, and laws prior to operating any military equipment or vehicles. Government vehicles (military tactical, General Services Administration (GSA), or leased vehicles that are operated by Contractor personnel) shall be used for official purposes only in satisfying the requirements of this contract. These vehicles shall be operated and maintained IAW DoD 4500.36 (&#8220;Acquisition, Management, and Use of DoD Non-Tactical Vehicles&#8221;) and any applicable regulation of the DOD Component concerned. Trained and licensed Contractor employees are authorized to use commercial vehicles (such as GSA motor pool fleet vehicles) as well as tactical vehicles (such as the High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicles (HMMWVs) or similar wheeled tactical vehicles) to accomplish the requirements of the PWS and in support of mission requirements as directed in writing by the COR. No cost shall be incurred by Contractor personnel on this contract for the use of Government furnished vehicles.

                        1.6.21.2 Government Provided Transportation: Contract personnel are authorized to travel by Military Air/Sea/Land conveyance for medical emergencies and as required to perform the assigned mission as authorized by DOD 4515.11-R, Chapter 2, (&#8220;Air Transportation Eligibility&#8221;) and AR 95-1(&#8220; Flight Regulations&#8221;). Upon request, individuals shall present proper identification and a copy of this authorization prior to travel by Government conveyance. When travel on Government conveyance is known or anticipated, a statement authorizing the individual to travel via that means shall be included in the Government approved Letter of Authorization (LOA) prior to travel. In some instances, Military Air (MILAIR) is the only prudent conveyance option and is allocable under this contract with advance notification and approval by the KO or COR.

                        1.6.22 Transition-In (also referred to as &#8220;Phase-In&#8221;) Activities:  During the phase-in period, the Contractor shall become familiar with performance requirements in order to commence full performance of services forty-five (45) calendar days after task order award.

                        1.6.22.1 Personnel Hiring/Processing Time:  The Contractor shall submit all key positions resumes within 24 hours of task order award. All other resumes and the personnel qualification tracking sheet shall be submitted during the transition period and as changes occur thereafter. The Contractor shall fill all key positions within 15 days of task order award and all other positions within 45 days of task order award. The Contractor will be authorized payment for the initial security processing time and the travel time to the assigned duty station. This coverage shall be limited to 30 days of in-processing per person. Charges beyond the 30-day limit shall not be charged to the Government. The Contractor shall bear all costs exceeding 30 days. Written notification shall be provided to COR immediately upon a key personnel vacancy.

                        &#9;&#9;Deliverable A010 &#8211; Key Personnel Resumes

                        1.6.22.2&#9; The following activities must occur during the phase-in period:

                        &#9;(i)&#9;Prior to charging direct time on this task order (excluding the Transition CLIN), the Contractor shall ensure that key personnel have been approved in writing by the COR as meeting the position qualifications.

                        &#9;(ii)&#9;The Contractor shall submit requests for physical and network access at performance locations.

                        (iii)&#9;The Contractor shall ensure that all CMEs complete Information Assurance (IA) Training (required for Government systems access) and obtain a completion Certificate prior to entry on duty (EOD). The Contractor shall ensure all completion Certificates are sent to the responsible COR to confirm compliance prior to EOD. Initially, non-CAC access to AKO is required to complete IA training. However, CMEs must obtain a CAC prior to EOD.

                        1.6.23 Transition-Out Activities: The Contractor shall cooperate with the Government to transition these efforts at the conclusion of the task order.  The Contractor shall submit a Transition-Out Plan for the orderly phase-out of the contracted operations at the end of the contract that describes the orderly turnover of facilities, equipment, and records and helps ensure continuity of service. The Contractor&#39;s planned phase-out procedures shall not disrupt or adversely affect the day-to-day conduct of Government business. The Government will review this deliverable for technical content and format. If the Government rejects the submitted plan, the Contractor shall make appropriate corrections and resubmit within 30 calendar days of notice of the rejection. The Contractor shall provide the Transition-Out Plan no later than 90 calendar days prior to the end of the contract period of performance to the Government.

                        &#9;&#9;  Deliverable:  A011&#8211; Transition Phase Out Plan

                        1.6.23.1 The Contractor shall plan and perform the following activities during the phase-out period:

                        (i)&#9;Ensure all services and performance objectives required by the PWS and contract are met throughout the phase-out period.

                        (ii)&#9;Transfer Data.  Provide copies of all unclassified and classified instructions, records, databases, contract performance metric data, vendor points of contact, and all other procedures developed by the Contractor in the performance of this contract to the COR.

                        &#9;Deliverable A012 &#8211; Transfer Data Report

                        (iii)&#9;Inventory the Organization&#8217;s IT Equipment.  Update and validate the authoritative IT equipment (hardware and software) list with the Government and the successor.

                        &#9;Deliverable A013 &#8211; Inventory of IT Equipment

                        (iv)&#9;Inventory and Inspect Government Furnished Equipment (GFE).  Perform joint inventories and inspections of all GFE, facilities, and property with the Government and the successor.

                        &#9;Deliverable A014 &#8211; Inventory of GFE List

                        (v)&#9;Return GFE.  Turn over to each organization&#8217;s COR all GFE and supplies.

                        (vi)&#9;Relinquish access badge(s), CACs, and official passports (if issued) to the COR or appropriate security administration personnel or office and follow the organization&#8217;s procedures for removal of access to all networks.

                        1.6.24&#9;In/Out Processing:  The Contractor&#8217;s Facility Security Officer (FSO) must provide to the COR the following information on all CMEs for input into the INSCOM In/Out Processing Portal.

                        &#9;&#9;Key Personnel Requirements:
